name: Mandrake (Dudaim)
uses: HISTORICAL STUDY ONLY - DO NOT USE
Genesis 30: Rachel and Leah bargain for mandrakes
Song of Solomon: erotic imagery with mandrakes
Historical (dangerous): fertility charm, love magic, anesthetic
sacredSignificance: Biblical love and fertility plant. Rachel desperately wanted mandrakes for fertility, but Leah (not Rachel) conceived instead - teaching that fertility comes from God, not herbs. Symbolizes human desire vs divine will.
preparationMethods: Can cause delirium, hallucinations, seizures, coma, death
This entry is for HISTORICAL and MYTHOLOGICAL study ONLY
safetyWarnings: No safe dose - can be fatal
Keep away from children and pets

jewish.usage: Biblical narrative (Genesis 30, Song of Solomon). Not used in practice.
jewish.significance: Lesson that fertility is divine gift, not magical result. Symbol of love and desire.

greek.usage: Myth of Myrrha/Adonis. Historical surgical anesthetic (dangerous).
greek.significance: Transformation, tears of sorrow becoming healing (mythology)

folklore.usage: Screaming root legend, dog harvesting method, anthropomorphic root
folklore.significance: Dangerous power requiring special knowledge to harvest

description: Mandrake (Dudaim) is a figure from ancient mythology.
